snippet.textDisplay:
15:32 - Scholar just made it so there is mimic in NG+, which I think is 10 times better than just having a mimic in NG

21:03 - Spiders in Scholar are actually afraid of fire which in my opinion totally justifies additional spiders and makes the area overall way more enjoyable

22:08 - Even though you corrected yourself in the video, I think it's still better in Scholar than vanilla simply because fighting a miniboss right after a major boss is kinda meh

22:34 - At the very least more loot, armor and invaders, I haven't played vanilla as much as Scholar so I don't remember gutter in vanilla that well

23:55 - Because if you fight them in vanilla other enemies gank you, thus it's changed in Scholar because 2 primal knights is already a challenge without some royal knights shooting/charging at you


24:27 - In Scholar masks don't shoot you untill you open that chest, while in vanilla they shoot you right as you enter the room

26:47 - While I do agree that there are quite a lot of enemies, you can easily kill them with a bow, it actually trivializes Shrine of Amana to a complete joke of an area. I can't disagree that it's not really obvious and most (if not all) of the players who walk into Shrine of Amana for the first time don't have an upgraded bow. Is it a bullshit area? - no, but is it a sudden "fuck you if you don't have ranged weapon"? - yeah and it's not very pleasant :P (also use gowers ring and ring of magic resist (YOU GET IT IN DRANGLEIC CASTLE RIGHT BEFORE/AFTER LOOKING GLASS KNIGHT), it's very good for this area)

30:18 - I think they tried to reward exploring that way, although I agree that they could've at least somehow told that "hey, you lighted all the torches, COME BACK". Dark Souls 2 in general rewards you for exploring the ares one or two more times, getting into every corner and interacting with all things (most of the time they reward you for that, sometimes they punish you for that ;)

I do agree that vanilla did *some* things better than Scholar, but I couldn't disagree more that vanilla is better than Scholar. Oh no, Scholar actually makes you play through location and complete them instead of running through like a headless chicken. And points about ganks always make me laugh, because it's bullshit. Wow, a whole *five* enemies in Iron Keep, damn, it's unplayable. 

I also recommend you going through NG+ in Scholar, tho maybe try to summon phantoms this time, NG+ in DS2 can get really hard sometimes.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm glad you highlighted many of these changes, though I think one thing that makes up for Scholar's additional enemies, that isn't mentioned in this video, is that in Vanilla DS2 enemy encounters often have chain aggro. Which makes aggro behave so much differently from version to version. In Scholar's it's much easier to kill enemies one at a time, but in the Vanilla version, often times aggroing one enemy will aggro several in the area. This leads to a lot of the insane ganks in the vanilla version. You can see this very quickly in the first bonfire in Forest of the Giants, in Vanilla aggroing one dude aggros at least 4 others, with an archer with increased range. No Man's Wharf has a similar thing, there's a house where if you aggro two vikings, three will come up the stairs. The Shrine of Amana has the same thing, the knights will often aggro alongside the magic users, the hippo would often aggro too, which for me makes the Vanilla version of this area MUCH worse. This maybe harder to notice as a melee character naturally, but as a ranged character it's quite noticeable.

I think a lot of misconceptions about Scholar's come from veterans coming to Scholar's after having played vanilla near release. Having partially forgotten how crazy Vanilla could get, so the ganks in Scholar's feels extra, even when it's not extra compared to Vanilla. I'm included in this, I played a bit of Scholar's a few years back and thought the ganks were ridiculous so I gave up. Came back to it last month, and comparing it to videos of Vanilla, and it's often times more ridiculous in Vanilla. The ganks are still there in Scholar's, and they still suck imo, but it's more manageable. Though I do think Scholar is a bit easier, either I've gotten much better at Dark Souls over the years, but many bosses feel easier.

I think something not mentioned in many comparison videos is that on a whole, enemy locations and item placement conforms to lore better in Scholar's. They put more thought into a lot of it, and it's easy to tell. Heide's Tower has a lot of Heide knights, because it's their castle. Aldia's Keep has many of his experiments near by. Dragon Aerie warns about the eggs because if you break the eggs, the dragons will wake up, the wyrm will also break the bridge on the lead up to the Shrine. And the Shrine is mostly peaceful, alongside the Ancestral Dragon.

snippet.textDisplay:
Vanilla DS2, 100%

*Presses play*

Edit: agreed, the run up to Velstadt and the Dragon Earie are better in Sinners. They improved the dragon area so much it confuses me they messed up everything else.

And that was always the point of scholar, to inprove upon the lore. They did so with the soldiers in Forest of the Fallen, attacking those trees, they did so in the Earie with the dragon warriors, they somehow failed to do so with the Heide knights, and overall they upped the lore with the items. I didn't care about Aldia but like there  is now an ending where you don't kindle the first flame.

But all of this bleaks in comparison to the changes in enemy positions and aggro behavior. I never needed to farm in vanilla so to me the flow of vanilla was better except for that ridiculous speedbump before Velstadt. Of the top of my head forest of the fallen, Heide's tower, no mans warf, the room before smelter, the whole of Brightstone cove and shrine of Amana in Sinners all break the flow with these "gotcha" moments that serve no purpose because they are all gank situations that simply need to be resolved like the vanilla room before Velstadt.

If DS2 gave you invincibility frames when opening a door or going through a fog I don't think there would be a controversy surrounding the scholar edition. But the game doesn't and Sinners was not build with that fact in mind.

Also 60 fps and certain attacks (like the two handed great club heavy attack that has a lingering aspect to it) makes your weapons degrade faster then 30fps, little fun fact.

The reason why the statue was added to Things Betwixt was because, in vanilla people who started NG+ could have their character gender swapped due to a bug, so the coffin was a way for them to easily revert that problem. 

Since the bug was patched by the time of sinner, they didn't remove the coffin, just made it harder to access as a feature.

snippet.textDisplay: Holy. There´s something about DS2 that I really like and I want to think that I like it not only for the sake of being a contrarian lol. I think what it draws me to this game it´s the world. For example, I think DS3 is far of a superior game than DS2, but I don´t enjoy the world of DS3, I know that´s suppose to be decaying, but I enjoy many locations in DS2 and the variety of them (I don´t care if the map is interconnected well or not, I just want to see as many cool locations as possible). Regarding your video, I remember playing Scholar and having a pretty bad time at some locations, actually I didn´t finish the game, even though there were like 3 hours left. Now, I bought the Vanilla DS2 through Steam and I´ve been playing it and I´ve been enjoying it a lot. I whish you could´ve compared both of the Steam versions becuase both of them have almost identical graphics and run at 60 fps (also there´s people on PVP in the Vanilla Version).

Well. In my book, if the experience is more rewarding and fun in SotFS, that makes it the better version.
It doesn't matter to me if some areas got more annoying than others if its just barely since you will be more than prepared to deal with it in that version - shown by the number of deaths and playtime you had. 

I guess what I'm trying to say here is that the number of points given to each area cannot be used to strictly measure the quality of these versions when you have these other factors combined. 
Personally, I believe it's clear as day that SotFS is the better version judging by the info you presented.

snippet.textDisplay:
I was one of those"The original is way better than scholar, scholar made the game way harder" people before. But I just finished a replaythrough of the original and was getting really annoyed in certain areas that I found way easier in scholar. I realise now that what version is best is really up to personal preference. I like the original because of where items and enemies are laid out, fit the lore better, and sometimes gameplay. Like in the original, the key to light up the lost sinners arena was behind an optional boss, so you were rewarded for doing more. But the scholar just left it out in the open so that there isn't really a reason to fight that boss early before the lost sinner. But to be honest I think when I'm doing another replay I might just choose scholar since its seems better in most areas now that I'm not blinded, and putting them side by side made me realise how much better scholar looks.

Great video

snippet.textDisplay:
I'd say SotFS is slightly better overall in terms or lore, but in terms of gameplay it's basically a toss up, maybe Vanilla is a bit better though.
For example the Pursuer actually pursues you, that's his job, to kill the undead, so him being everywhere makes sense in terms of lore.
A drake mini-boss being outside of Ornstein's chamber also makes more sense lore-wise. Ornstein betrayed Gwen and followed the Nameless King, who got stripped of his godhood for teaming up with the dragons in DS1 lore, so Orenstien teamed up with Drakes and Dragons makes sense for his lore too. Also Heide Knights being in HEIDE'S Tower makes sense.
Also I'd say that SotSF has more enemies overall, but their positioning and agro ranges are very different. For example, there are a lot more undead to fight in the Forest of Fallen giants after you climb the ladder in SotFS, but you need to go out of your way to agro all the undead, meanwhile all the undead are automatically agroed at you in Vanilla, I'd say that actually makes SotSF slightly better because you only need to fight more undead if you are either carelss, or want to go out of your way to kill all the undead.
You can fight the body of Vengarl in SotFS, but it's in a different location, it's hidden in the shaded woods. It makes more sense lore-wise for his body to be there because he was presumably decapitated there.
I could go on and on, but I think you get the point. Now the lore being slightly better does not really matter if the game is worse, but I think the lore being stronger should be noted for SotSF.

snippet.textDisplay:
Speaking as a DS2 newbie I can safely say there were exactly 3 locations in Scholar that I just down right disliked dealing with the amount of enemies in each, Lost Bastille hallway right before the Ruin Sentinels boss, Iron Keep's walk up to the Smelter Demon, and The Shrine of Amana. Although non of those areas were a problem at all in NG+ since I knew what to expect for the first two and having a thrusting weapon with long range made a complete joke of most of the enemies in those two areas.

That said in NG+, that dragon keep is terrifying, this time instead of the dragon armor dudes just chilling and watching you they all agro'd on me after I passed them, I just sprinted past everyone and the last set of stairs that has like 24 of them is just so terrifying lmao. Thankfully they don't enter the Dragon's arena so you can at least get the ashen heart in peace.

snippet.textDisplay: The video got a lot of comments so it's quite possible someone already told you but there actually is a bonfire in Brightstone Cove Tseldora in the vanilla version, you just couldn't find it, apparently. When I was playing I also took while to find it, but there is a bonfire inside one of the tents, while in the sinner version they replaced the bonfire to outside the tent and made it mode obvious and easy to see. Personally I don't have much of an opinion on that, while I like the idea of having to be observant of your surroundings to improve your gameplay, I also think it's kind of annoying when you just won a boss fight and is entering a new area, and you obviously have a lot of souls on you waiting to be used on upgrades and all so you absolutely don't wanna fucking die, and you can't find a bonfire.

snippet.textDisplay:
Oh, I forgot to mention. About the "BLONDE LION CLAN WARRIOR" and the Body Of Vengarl.

It's implied that the "Blonde" Lion Warrior is some kind of clan leader, so he drops unique gear. Not only is he the only enemy that drops the head piece of the Lion Warrior set (the Lion Warrior Helm, which is more like a chained headdress), he can drop an advanced version of the Lion Clan Warrior chest piece called the Red Lion Warrior Cape (which offers higher stats, especially curse resistance). Since he doesn't respawn, it's recommended that you go in with lucky gear and probably use a rusted coin for increased drop rates for the best chance of catching that gear. Incidentally, every piece of the set reduces fall damage (just like Shalquoir's "cat pants" because you know, cats).

And this brings me to Vengarl's body. In Vanilla, the location of the Golden Lion is actually in a chamber under Manscorpion Tark's location that can be accessed from a hallway near where Tark hangs out. In scholar, as you mentioned, the lion was moved. Both entrances to his old chamber are now blocked by Petrified Stone Lions, but if you bring one back to life and clear the path, the chamber is now the home of Vengarl's Body. It's a tighter area which makes for a much harder fight, but he's there. And if you walk outside the chamber and look down, you're literally a stone's throw away from Vengarl's head. Something you think the head might have realized since he says he can feel his body. But yeah, hope this answers your questions about both.

snippet.textDisplay: My biggest gripe with Scholar is how many enemies they just plop down without seemingly any care. Heide's is a great example. Going into lore a bit, the Heide Knights abandoned their city because they realized it was falling to ruin, hence why they're spread throughout the world in vanilla. They left behind those mindless stone giants as guards, because obviously a mindless golem isn't going to abandon its post willingly. In Scholar, they fill the entire area with them, because more hard enemies = good game (I guess?). Frankly, I'm also just not a big fan of how many absolute gankfests they squeezed into Scholar, I guess because they wanted it to be harder above all else, even if that difficulty isn't well made.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think you're probably undermining how much the statues affect the gameplay... Especially during the tutorial, since-, you know, IT'S THE TUTORIAL
Also wdym you give the point to SotFS in the Lost Sinner's fight because you can light the torches right away. Getting the key elsewhere basically makes it so the fight with the Gargoyles is 100% skippable since the key is THE item you get from the fight. The key doesn't feel earned
Also the thing with the Heide Knights??? You might find them annoying, sure, but they were an especial enemy in Vanilla, like some kind of Black Knight for DS2. Even if you don't like them, they are optional challenges for the player that give good early game weapons. Instead they butchered an entire area (Heide) by spamming them and removing what they added to the zones they were originally in

Alsoooo you don't really need to farm for the Ruin Sentinels, you usually go through Heide and No-Man's Wharf before the Lost Bastille

snippet.textDisplay:
So, basically, you're a massochist who loves fighting a shit ton of enemies for no good reason? The only area that Sinner's edition slightly improved on was the gank fight just prior to Velstadt. Literally every other area in the game is like the developers threw in a bunch of random enemies and items with no thought for strategy, fun or design. Sinner's edition is objectively an awful game whereas Vanilla is a deeply flawed but still very fun game. The biggest sin of the remake is that it does not even include the much more well designed layout of the original version. Instead they forced all modern gamer's into playing their complete bullshit version with 10x the enemies, now placed at random.

Edit: Should have added that i still upvoted the film as it was well done and entertaining. If other people prefer Scholar that is fine, but in my mind, it destroyed a game i previously loved, kinda like the special edition of the original Star Wars.

snippet.textDisplay:
The problem in Iron Keep (and most of SoFS) is not just the number of enemies (yes, there aren't that many) but it's the aggro and the pacing, when you have all the enemies chasing you in small hallways it's not fun or a challenge, it is annoying and unfair.

I recommend the video called: "Dark Souls 2 is a Good Game, and Scholar RUINED It!" by Feeble King and: "Did I Play Dark Souls 2 Wrong? Or is Scholar the Worst Souls Game Ever!" also from Feeble King.

Where it is better explained, how the pacing in the vanilla game is good and how SoFS ruined it with its excessive aggro and other things it added.
snippet.textOriginal:
The problem in Iron Keep (and most of SoFS) is not just the number of enemies (yes, there aren't that many) but it's the aggro and the pacing, when you have all the enemies chasing you in small hallways it's not fun or a challenge, it is annoying and unfair.

I recommend the video called: "Dark Souls 2 is a Good Game, and Scholar RUINED It!" by Feeble King and: "Did I Play Dark Souls 2 Wrong? Or is Scholar the Worst Souls Game Ever!" also from Feeble King.

Where it is better explained, how the pacing in the vanilla game is good and how SoFS ruined it with its excessive aggro and other things it added.

Gotta disagree abt your take on Heide knight in the forest of giants, Heide knights were meant to be the equivalent of the black knights on the other games. Which is a really good concept. They will drop unique weapon on each encounter which is most of the weapons are really good, in fact, it's actually pretty op for early game. So, if you're managed to kill them in the early on, you are definitely rewarded.

But sotfs changed it, they drop them in just one place and all of them will be aggro after you killed the dragonrider. It's so stupid, and now you need to farm them in order to get their weapons, which is really annoying

I've only played SOTFS, but the amount of enemies never bothered me. It made me pay more attention to the environments and use that to my advantage, which was fun.

Like the bit you mention in the Lost Bastille where a bunch of royal swordsman come out at you. If you run back across the bridge you can then run in a circle around the battlement with the broken stone and you can make them all fall to their deaths. I was laughing like a maniac because the level design let me turn an "Oh, crap" situation into a "Ha! Booyeah!" situation. 

For the record, I'm not very good at souls games. I really like them, but I am at best mediocre.

snippet.textDisplay:
Don't really agree honestly aggro ranges are absolutely insane in Scholar. I think the only area i would say is straight up better is the run up to Ancient Dragon, and maybe the dragon itself. (also maybe the cell with the boss weapon guy in it ) Vanilla requires much more exploration, if you don't look around you will end up with like 3/4 estus by the end whereas is Scholar everything is kind of handed to you. I never found myself farming in either one as bosses give an absurd amount of souls. Scholar randomly blocks places with branches of yore which discourages the player to even explore when you wont even remember where you have seen and not.

For sure there are some better item placements and little mechanics like scaring the spiders, but i just feel like overall i was way less frustrated in vanilla. Either way the game feels awful without 96/99 agility so you are pretty much required to put your first 20 levels to adaptability just to start playing the game properly and not feeling like every attack is hitting you while you dodge. If they simply fixed that in scholar along with aggro ranges then it would have bene fine. Scholar randomly has like 14 statues to use branches on whereas vanilla only has like 5 at most.

snippet.textDisplay: Very nice video, I'm working on the platinum for Scholar now after finishing 3. I'm not sure if someone else mentioned it but in Dragon Shrine, the Dragon Knights will aggro you if you run past one of the Drakekeepers (Scholar). This makes the run back for the Ancient Dragon very tedious, as this is a mildly buggy fight, when Scholar has two Dragon Knight outside of the fog gate. Also one of the alternative perspectives on Dranglic is that it's very underwhelming as a later game area in Scholar compared to Vanilla. This was a fantastic video, but it's hard to replicate how a new player feels trying to navigate through the incredibly vast world and handle run backs so early on.

snippet.textDisplay:
Sinner is "harder" and not as well-paced or structured as vanilla because of enemy placement and aggro ranges, not necessarily enemy quantity. Adding more enemies generally doesn't mean much, but their placement and aggro ranges can have a huge impact on how the game plays. A really good example of the core issues with Scholar's encounter design is the trap encounter in the Forest of Fallen Giants that you need to do in order to get the White Sign Soapstone from Pate. In the original version, the enemies are much more spread out from one another and have smaller aggro ranges, allowing for a much more controlled set of encounters where the player can slowly work through all of the enemies at their own pace. In Scholar, however, they're all placed at the front of the hallway and they all aggro at the same time, so you have well over five enemies going through the doorway one by one right after Pate traps you inside, and they're all trying to attack you simultaneously. This makes the version of this encounter in Scholar very tedious and draining because you don't really have any openings, so you have to slowly pick away at them while kiting them around the relatively small room you're in and hope for the best.

Encounters like _that_ are the reason Sinner is trashed on for having enemy spam and ganks. It has little to do with the quantity of enemies in it and far more to do with its needless changes to enemy placements and aggro ranges that make the game more tedious to get through than it is difficult to get through. Vanilla had a few instances with similar or worse encounters, but overall Sinner is the inferior version of the game in this regard. Vanilla gives you far more control over the field than Sinner does, which also has the effect of giving you a lot more options for how to approach encounters. You would probably agree that Sinner is far worse overall in most cases if you weren't using the Spankplank (that's what my friend and I call the Greatsword), since the Spankplank does very high damage and can easily hit multiple enemies.

snippet.textDisplay: The reason they removed most of the crossbowmen in Sinner's Rise in Scholar is because in vanilla they could spawnkill you as soon as you respawn or teleport to the bonfire, especially if you were afk, so the only way to make that bonfire safe was to farm them until they were permanently dead. In Scholar they reduced it to one crossbowman and placed him far away from the bonfire in order to prevent players from losing their souls unfairly.
snippet.textOriginal: The reason they removed most of the crossbowmen in Sinner's Rise in Scholar is because in vanilla they could spawnkill you as soon as you respawn or teleport to the bonfire, especially if you were afk, so the only way to make that bonfire safe was to farm them until they were permanently dead. In Scholar they reduced it to one crossbowman and placed him far away from the bonfire in order to prevent players from losing their souls unfairly.

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm not aware of Adaptability improving your weapon animation speeds, but it increases Agility, which improves your invincibility frames and improves the throwing/animation speeds of various consumables like Estus Flasks and Throwing Knives. You can also level Attunement to increase your Agility and in turn your invincibility frames but at a slightly slower rate compared to Adaptability in exchange for more casting slots and faster casting speeds, so there's a risk/reward there where you can either spend more levels over the course of your playthrough on a stronger stat for a greater long term benefit or spend (waste) levels on a mediocre stat that gives you the amount of invincibility frames you want in the short term but makes it harder to reach your goals for other stats in the long term, which makes your build weaker in terms of DPS and/or survivability. There are also a few items in the game that you can equip to increase your ADP a bit in case you want to or need to, such as the Handmaid's Ladle (must be in one of your hands in order for the passive effect to work; it works while two-handing your primary weapon, so you don't need to be physically holding it) and three of the four pieces of the Peasant set that can be farmed in Brightcove Tseldora. https://darksouls2.wiki.fextralife.com/Peasant+Set

To be frank, ADP/Agility is overrated. You don't actually need it to be able to avoid most of the attacks in the game, having more Agility just makes the game easier by reducing how tight your dodge inputs need to be and/or by making spacing less necessary for avoiding attacks since with enough AGI you can roll through them instead. People have beaten the game at SL1 many times even without the Peasant set and Ladle, so ADP is definitely not a necessary stat.

Why... didn't you just get Dark Souls 2 (vanilla) on Steam? It looks better and runs at 60 FPS.

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you for calling out ng+.  ds2 put way more focus on ng+ and also way more focus on multiplayer (the side areas everyone complains about in the dlcs are specifically for co-op, and work a lot better in that context).  but the typical souls bro never summons and never plays ng+ and as such just aren't willing to engage with ds2's strengths.  yes, ds2 is still probably the weakest in the series.  Yes it was rushed, and unfinished, and was missing Miyazaki's touch.  but it tried some interesting stuff and pushed the souls series' most unique features in new ways and had a compelling take on the series lore and themes.

SotFS wins for me.

It is more lore friendly in the enemy placement and overall less empty, whilst providing more tools  early to make it fair.

Having said that, though. Drangleic Castle is very disappointing for me in SotFS, as every other area got improved, imo, the castle having less enemies and less variety made it feel pointless as hell.

Also, I don't necessarily think vanilla being "less annoying" is a good thing, because it got really boring to me.

snippet.textDisplay: For me I play dark souls two vanilla, and I got to play one of the DLCs before my PS3 went down the drain. I didn't get to play Dark Souls 2 again until scholar of the first sin, and I have to say I like scholar better. Not only does it contain every bit of DLC, but it also balances out a lot of the things that I did not like about vanilla. And it retains most of what I liked about vanilla in the first place. The PVP remained mostly intact, the build diversity remained mostly intact, I actually like the fact they put statues in areas to make the player not cheese some areas and get too strong, and the game still retains its strong sense of RPG mechanics. And that with all the changes to the enemy placements and the location of certain items is a breath of fresh for someone who plays Dark Souls 2 quite a bit. I find that the only thing that I genuinely do not like about Dark Souls 2 in general, is that when you have played the game to completion and then wait a few months or a year you play it again, for me personally I always forget where some areas are connected. The level design in the game is amazing, but I agree that how those levels are connected can sometimes be so confusing. But aside from that I don't have any real complaints with the game considering I have beaten the game 9 times at this point in my life. And that is coming from someone who has played every single fromsoft game since Demon Souls. The only fromsoft game I have not beaten happens to be sekiro. They just changed so much After Dark Souls 2 that I just can't get into it as much as I used to. I enjoyed my playthrough of Elden ring and bothered 100%, but never again will ever play Elden ring. On the other hand I always go back to Dark Souls 2 at least once or twice a year.

snippet.textDisplay:
This was an excellent video, and overall I agree with both your objective and bias points of view! It's funny almost since I was nearly thinking the same things your were saying.

I just beat SotFS yesterday for the first time, including all the DLC bosses. I beat vanilla DS2 round-about 3 years ago, so when I started SotFS I was a bit hazy on where to go and what to do at points (but a quick google always pointed me in the right direction). One thing that I clearly CLEARLY remember, even from 3 years ago, was how much I did not have a great time playing vanilla DS2. Strong bias here, I know, but as my memory of it is, it was so bad that when I finally did beat the game, I kinda told myself "nope, that's it, no NG+, never touching this game again with a 2-meter long pole". (I didn't have the DLCs btw).

I played a ton of DS1 and made a buncha videos even on that since it seems to be my favorite, played 3 into like NG+4 or something, and then of course Elden Ring rolled out and I lost like half a year to just playing that every day. I keep circling back to DS1 for some reason because to me, although its janky, it just "feels" enjoyable to play, and I can honestly say that SotFS might also be a game like that. 3 definitely is a circle back game, ER not so much because its just too damn big.

Anyways, about 1 week ago I decided to give SotFS a chance, and I have to say that I actually enjoyed it. I loved how you were constantly invaded by NPCs, loved how they gave you so many weapons and ways to easily level up not only the character, but all the Titanite they give you, the DLCs were very easy but enjoyable, I actually legit struggled with the Fume Knight boss fight and that'll probably live in my head now rent free, etc etc. There were some places though that were just a slog, like the run-ups to the second blue Smelter Demon and Sir Alonne were so bad that I just literally cleared the areas 12 times in a row so that enemies wouldn't respawn. I actually think I died more in SotFS (compared to you it was like half compared to vanilla), so completely the opposite, but also in SotFS I was always trying to explore every nook and cranny, and some bosses in the DLC were really tricky. In DS2, I was for some reason not that interested and mainly rushed through the game.
Well, not to go on now and write a small novel, I'd say SotFS is much much better, and I definitely will be replaying it in the near future :D
Nice work and keep up the great videos!

snippet.textDisplay:
You aren't expected to go to Sinner before No-Man's Wharf: No-Man's Wharf literally has you fight the Flexile Sentry, teleports you to the Lost Bastille, and then you find a second Flexile Sentry at Sinner's Rise. Poor reuse? Sure. But you did it out of order, that's a weird thing to nitpick

Also no, you do not have to fight Heide Knights at Heide's tower of Flame unless you've killed the Dragon Rider already. They completely ignore you otherwise. I don't know if this is true in Vanilla but it absolutely is the case in Scholar

Even at SL1 the spider area is complete non issue, use a torch. It's free, you should never get hit except for maybe fall damage. Can't speak for vanilla but If Scholar has more spiders then.. I'd wager it's still a complete non issue. Don't need a torch for the boss fight, just the boss run. Light the sconce inside the chapel looking building and you're golden.

Headless man is in the Shaded Woods, behind one for the statue guys right before you get to the scorpion man.

Black Gulch only has two invaders, both can be completely ignored or baited off the edge. Your effigies make no difference.

The Dragon Warriors WILL attack you if you ignore the big bois. They will not let you run past. Same thing at the 1v1 right before the Dragon: They will swarm if you try to run past, but they wont attack while you talk to the dragon.

Also it is a little annoying that you refer to Scholar as Sinner's but eh, not the biggest issue

Did you play the DLC?

At the end of the day, I probably like Sinners better because of the better gameplay and graphics. You’re right… XBox360 looks washed out. You did a lot of work to make this video and it’s appreciated

snippet.textDisplay:
That moment when you find out about the Bonfire Ascetic and/or the Warriors of Blue Covenant, both of which are fundamental to farming enemies in DS2 because they respawn entire areas and/or prevent enemies staying 'perma-dead'. 

That said, I found DS2 vanilla to still be fairly friendly with its levels. The big roadblock is Ruin Sentinels, but the walk back is so much more manageable in Vanilla that it makes for a more enjoyable time compared to scholar. 
Also, worth noting is that levels in DS2 matter a lot LESS than in other souls games. 

Start scaling of weapons is really low, so a similar stated character may struggle a lot more if using 2 weapons of different upgrades. Weapon upgrades are a huge boost to dps, and the big benefit of levels is either min requirements for certain weapons, adaptability, stam, and vitality.

snippet.textDisplay:
I played the original DS2 only once on the PS3, and I played a LOT of SOTFS on the PC (700 hours), haven't watched the "original video" you mentioned (yet), but I got a lot of comments to make about this video, so here's a few notes, I hope they're useful.

0:45 it helps, but it just increases your resistance, so you still need to stack it with fire resistant equipment and consumables (Flash Sweat is great).

1:13 ADP (and ATN) changes your AGL stat. AGL is the important number, you should get it to 100 as fast as possible (25 ADP for non magic users or 30 ATN + 17 ADP for magic *pyros, hexers, and miracles included* users is enough, no more lvls needed). I don't think it makes you swing your weapons faster, but you cast spells faster, have more i-frames during rolls, and use items faster indeed.

5:00 there is a lore reason, as their name suggests, they pursue/ hunt and kill undead. Undead were shunned by the kingdom, so they were sent to the Lost Bastille to be locked up, or to Huntsman Copse to be tortured for eternity, and the Pursuers are just one more facet of this prejudice. I don't have a problem with them because they are optional.

DS2 has a lot of poorly implemented stuff, the Pursuers just kind of show up a lot at random times at the beginning of the game, and then they're just gone (fun fact: in SOTFS you can face 2 at the same time in Castle Dragleic in NG+ and beyond. I don't know if they're there in the vanilla game), bosses in general were supposed to be more of a threat before the bossfight in their arena (leftover of this is Duke's Dear Freja appearing early in NG+, and any damage you deal to it carrying over for the real bossfight).

5:47 these enemies appear here on SOTFS, but only on NG+ and beyond.

8:20 in SOTFS there's no need to fight all the Heide knights, but I can't blame you for thinking this. They aggro only after you kill the Dragonrider, so you can kill the old Dragon Slayer first (only 2 Heide Knights), get the ring of binding (1 more Heide knight), and then after killing the Dragonrider there's no reason for you to ever go to this area again. I am more forgiving because this is an optional area, but I agree it sucks if you do it the natural way (killing Dragonrider first FEELS like the intended way, which makes the area suck unfortunately).

15:05 do the enemies aggro from further away? I don't remember how it was on my PS3 days, but in SOTFS I feel like as soon as I poke my head into any room, at least 4 enemies start running to me, Iron Keep foces you to take your time and kill the enemies, it doens't annoy me too much, but I agree it can be sucky.

18:54 I have no idea why this Lion Warrior is different, but it doesn't respawn and it has a very low chance of dropping the Lion Warriors headpeace, or a recolor of the chespiece, good luck burning Ascetics if you want them for any reason.

21:07 the spiders hate fire, so lit your torch and enjoy the lack of annoying spiders.

22:11 he is right after this petrified enemy at 18:48 it never made sense to me for he to be in a room with a primal bonfire, I the optional encouter of SOTFS makes more sense to me.

23:07 I may be completely wrong here, but I THINK 2 npcs always invade here, and after you defeat one they don't invade again.

One thing I'm sure of. The amount of effigies in your inventory don't affect invasions, there are some scripted npc invasions, and unlike other Souls games, in SOTFS you can always be invaded by other players, no matter if hollow or human, if the area boss is alive or dead, only burning a human effigy at a bonfire stops invasions for that area for 30 minutes (also stops coop).

I played all Dark Souls in order DS1 Prepare to Die > DS2 > DS2 SOTFS > DS3. I disliked DS2 the first time I played it, I considered DS1 better, and then DS3 even betterer. But these days SOTFS is my favourite, mainly because it's the one I feel have more replay value, the fact that I can just farm 1000000 souls and bypass the 4 "Great Ones" (Or use Ascetics to kill The Rotten about 5 times) and go straight to Drangleic Castle makes ds2 the one with most freedom and opportunity for variety in my opinion.
snippet.textOriginal:
I played the original DS2 only once on the PS3, and I played a LOT of SOTFS on the PC (700 hours), haven't watched the "original video" you mentioned (yet), but I got a lot of comments to make about this video, so here's a few notes, I hope they're useful.

0:45 it helps, but it just increases your resistance, so you still need to stack it with fire resistant equipment and consumables (Flash Sweat is great).

1:13 ADP (and ATN) changes your AGL stat. AGL is the important number, you should get it to 100 as fast as possible (25 ADP for non magic users or 30 ATN + 17 ADP for magic *pyros, hexers, and miracles included* users is enough, no more lvls needed). I don't think it makes you swing your weapons faster, but you cast spells faster, have more i-frames during rolls, and use items faster indeed.

5:00 there is a lore reason, as their name suggests, they pursue/ hunt and kill undead. Undead were shunned by the kingdom, so they were sent to the Lost Bastille to be locked up, or to Huntsman Copse to be tortured for eternity, and the Pursuers are just one more facet of this prejudice. I don't have a problem with them because they are optional.

DS2 has a lot of poorly implemented stuff, the Pursuers just kind of show up a lot at random times at the beginning of the game, and then they're just gone (fun fact: in SOTFS you can face 2 at the same time in Castle Dragleic in NG+ and beyond. I don't know if they're there in the vanilla game), bosses in general were supposed to be more of a threat before the bossfight in their arena (leftover of this is Duke's Dear Freja appearing early in NG+, and any damage you deal to it carrying over for the real bossfight).

5:47 these enemies appear here on SOTFS, but only on NG+ and beyond.

8:20 in SOTFS there's no need to fight all the Heide knights, but I can't blame you for thinking this. They aggro only after you kill the Dragonrider, so you can kill the old Dragon Slayer first (only 2 Heide Knights), get the ring of binding (1 more Heide knight), and then after killing the Dragonrider there's no reason for you to ever go to this area again. I am more forgiving because this is an optional area, but I agree it sucks if you do it the natural way (killing Dragonrider first FEELS like the intended way, which makes the area suck unfortunately).

15:05 do the enemies aggro from further away? I don't remember how it was on my PS3 days, but in SOTFS I feel like as soon as I poke my head into any room, at least 4 enemies start running to me, Iron Keep foces you to take your time and kill the enemies, it doens't annoy me too much, but I agree it can be sucky.

18:54 I have no idea why this Lion Warrior is different, but it doesn't respawn and it has a very low chance of dropping the Lion Warriors headpeace, or a recolor of the chespiece, good luck burning Ascetics if you want them for any reason.

20:10 if you're part of the rat covenant (grave of saints in Majula's well) every enemy inside doors of Pharros become passive. It's also an optional area that have 1 interesting weapon (Santier's Spear. No scaling, 500 durability, if you break it the moveset changes)

21:07 the spiders hate fire, so lit your torch and enjoy the lack of annoying spiders.

22:11 he is right after this petrified enemy at 18:48 it never made sense to me for he to be in a room with a primal bonfire, I the optional encouter of SOTFS makes more sense to me.

23:07 I may be completely wrong here, but I THINK 2 npcs always invade here, and after you defeat one they don't invade again.

One thing I'm sure of. The amount of effigies in your inventory don't affect invasions, there are some scripted npc invasions, and unlike other Souls games, in SOTFS you can always be invaded by other players, no matter if hollow or human, if the area boss is alive or dead, only burning a human effigy at a bonfire stops invasions for that area for 30 minutes (also stops coop).

I played all Dark Souls in order DS1 Prepare to Die > DS2 > DS2 SOTFS > DS3. I disliked DS2 the first time I played it, I considered DS1 better, and then DS3 even betterer. But these days SOTFS is my favourite, mainly because it's the one I feel have more replay value, the fact that I can just farm 1000000 souls and bypass the 4 "Great Ones" (Or use Ascetics to kill The Rotten about 5 times) and go straight to Drangleic Castle makes ds2 the one with most freedom and opportunity for variety in my opinion.

snippet.textDisplay:
The gold lion clan warrior appeared in vanilla as a petrified enemy in the lower shaded woods on the way to the black knight glaive. It's special not just because of that, but because it drops the lion warrior headpiece and IIRC is the only way to obtain it. Also, the key to the bastille in vanilla is at the end of the belfry luna branch which can be reached via the pharros statue below the soldier's rest bonfire.

And hiede's tower of flame is actually meant to be your second or optional harder first location. No man's wharf which is after it leads to the back entrance of lost bastille, so you're clearly not supposed to go and finish lost bastille before it. so the inclusion of the flexile sentry makes sense at the end of the bastille more than the enhanced hollows, which are more of an aldia's keep thing. That's why the ruin sentinels are also so hard: you're supposed to hit that wall, go back to majula and explore a bit, go through heide's tower of flame and no man's wharf, unlock the back bastille, and by the time you're back at the ruin sentinels you'd be strong enough to beat them.

The black dragon armor is acquired through the dragon covenant rewards. You get it via items, you don't equip it. So it's kind of a pvp only thing.


It really seems like you didn't spend much time exploring in vanilla.

snippet.textDisplay:
the pve in DS2 is god awful, BUT the actual character gameplay is super fun, it was heavy, impactful, every strike meant something, because of how slow the game felt compared to the other games.

but out of the 40 bosses the game has, only 8 of them id consider to be "Really well designed", and 4-5 of them to be "Okay", the rest are just....slow....boring....bad rehashed versions of bosses that already exist, gank fights that are not only annoying, but incredibly easy.

DS2 in general was more of a Quantity over Quality game, the only things it did better than most of the other games, was the feel of combat, power stancing, NG+ invasions (not arenas), and build potential, but between all its other problems? nah man, its 100% the weakest of the souls titles, because of its poor execution of the good ideas that it actually has, but credit where credit is due.

at least in demons souls you could have fun getting lost, and was a solid experience with a level of consistency in its locales and enemies, even though its 100% the easiest souls game, DS2 just throws dudes in armour at you, has you fight twelve at once, and declares itself "Difficult", DS2 is also the HARDEST souls game (sekiro for hardest fromsoft game), but its the hardest for all the wrong reasons, with the aforementioned constant gank squads of annoying enemies while you get shot at from fifty other locations after dipping your toe into a new zone....im looking at you Iron Keep.......

Edit:  Frozen Wastes is the most hated locale, not Iron Keep, even though Iron Keep literally reduced me to angry ugly crying....i dare ANYONE to legitimately go through that area with Champions Covenant active, without completely skipping it somehow (spoilers...you probably wont) avoiding the bombardment of arrows and the half dozen armoured two-shotting knights that bum rush you the second you enter, good fucking luck.

oh, and forlorn can randomly show up there, i swear, any time i actually made some kind of progress in that area, he would show up, and kill me, and my pain would repeat all over again.

snippet.textDisplay:
With Iron Keep, I believe the reason why so many people say that it has "many" more enemies is because the aggro range and the placement of the enemies compared to Vanilla DS2 mean that you are far more likely to be getting assaulted by a bunch of dudes all at once and massively reduces the amount of safe areas.
The haphazard, specifically annoying placement of the enemies as well as other tweaks makes each additional enemy feel like 3 or 4 and the encounters end up being way less interesting and way more annoying than in vanilla

snippet.textDisplay:
- amazing video, a lot of work and dedication including the acquisition of an already ancient artifact that is the xbox360 + game
- "I don't know Vanila very well" but IMO Sinner > Vanila, and here Sinner wins by a huge margin much better placement of enemies in the world in terms of challenge and world logic (lore dude)
- "lord's private chamber" fight with Vengarl's body in that place is stupid, how did he get there? (I use the empty room argument that Sinner is better .... "what's wrong with me?") an empty room is better than filling it with something that doesn't fit and so much more often happens in Vanila although even Sinner doesn't get full rid of the problem fully
- I'll defend "Shrine of Amana" such a big difference between Vanila and Sinner is due to the fact that originally it was supposed to be one of the early locations, but ended up near the end (complexity of the lore + indecision of the creators) so in Vanila this place is way too easy, but in turn they dont wanted to change so much this location in Sinner so they just added more enemies, simple solution but not good
- it seems to me that we gain more souls and items in Sinner, which means we can check out more sets instead of focusing on one weapon, although here it should be noted that some of the preiots in Vanila have a 100% drop rate where in Sinner it can be as low as 1%, so specific preiots can force us to farm
- in spite of the fact that you have to farm and your opponents don't respawn after nth death Sinners is still more accessible
- more than a year of creating DLC, which are already part of Sinner, was not only spent on creating new content, but also on fixing bugs and fine-tuning the balance of the game, I do not know how to check now how many patches there were, but DS2 was the most supported game by Bandai Namco/From Software
- just supported the only thing I jealous of Vannila is the support of the creators this game had organized events or weapon skins
- i know some people complain about other achievements but it doesn't change anything in the game
- the change of library from dx9 to dx11 is a big change which is hard to see but it's the main reason why this game looks better and will be longer supported by the hardware and the community, and the community creates amazing mods that can be used even in network play, "Blue Acolyte" now you can have more information about who you play with and better matched people to play with (less ping, more activity), "DS2LightingEngine SotFS" you can make the game look better than new games
- I hope you will earn enough from this video to pay off the purchase of the console and game 😄
(The length of my comments is adapted to the length of the video)

snippet.textDisplay:
I think Dark Souls 2 is suck overall :). I bought original one on last sale because it was simply cheaper. By the time I played ds2 for first time I was very close to get 100% at ds1, so I thought that I won't have any problems beating it. It turnus out that the game is TERRIBLE comparing to DS1. Thoose waepons made out of paper because they were getting broken so goddamn fast, cutting a piece of your max HP after every death, big amouns of enemies everywhere, lack of Estus Flasks and healing at all at the first half of the game is so annoying.... I remember I was playing like a Hedgehog, afraid of every unknown corner of the room and constantly using shield because I was afraid to die so I will suffer reaching my lost souls even more. Also I don't like that character movement, I can't feel any effort of rolling/doging/doing a parry, or at least try to do a parry, because I used to DS1 timings so much. Thank god I found a guy on Steam Disscousions who wanted to rebeat original game, because he haven't played it since SOFTS was released, he helped me really a lot, I am surely would not be able to beat the game without that guy, we made out almost a half of the game and he was a nice guy to talk. And speaking of Coop, this is the only thing I liked about DS2 because my Dark Souls journey started in late 2022, and it was Dark Souls Prepare to Die Edition, and Bandai Namco shuted down multiplayer by that time. Soul Memory is kinda frustrating but we dealt with it pretty much without any big problems. The game wasn't that bad, I even tried to play some DLC`s. I made out to get that CRown of Sunken King, but when I reached another Smelter Demon from "Crown of the Old Iron King" and died to it a hundred times... I just thought that is enough for me... DLC in Dark Souls 2, they feeled like random location without any story and clear objective, while DS1's dlc have a good story, bosses and characters. Right now I am playing DS3 , and this is much better than 2, especially visually it looks like technichal demo on Unreal Engine 5 :) I didn't expect that I can play something as beatifual as Dark Souls 3 on my computer. I will probably give a second chance for Dark Souls 2 sometime later, because for some reason I like rewinding things that I thought were bad a long time ago. 

I hope there are no major mistakes in my comment I don't know English that good, also this is likeley the biggest comment I have ever written, I really enjoyed your video. Have a great day!

snippet.textDisplay:
Lots of speculations are going on the part of adaptability. Adaptability on itself does NOT increase  your iframes neither it does increase action speed. AGL (substat) slightly increases use of consumables and it improves iframes. This stat could be gained through leveleing both ADP and ATT! There is also a ring in Brume Tower DLC which increases AGL stat.
Edit: SOTFS also DID NOT add any additional items in the game! It's true that some items were harder to get but the key from Lost Sinner's fight is just located in a different place (Gargoyle fight).
UPD2: You don't have to go to lost bastille after forst of the giants either. You have options. If you go to No Man's warf and approach the area from another side you can completely skip ruin sentinels. After dragon rider's fight there is also an option to go to huntsman's copse. If you have branch player may also go to shaded woods.  If one area is too difficult - try another!

there are less adds when fighting the skeletons in SOTFS
the iron keep is worse because of how the enemies agro especially if you completely lower the bridge
vengarl is in the shaded woods in sotfs you have to do a specific jump and use branches to get to him 
there are like 3 or 4 enemies that ring the bell in the crypt one will also climb out of the ground and there is an invisible one standing in the corner
they kinda ruined dragons aerie a bit in sotf in my opinion you can climb up what was a shortcut and just completely skip the area as soon as you arrive 
yes you can get the dragon armour you have to take a dragon egg from the shrine to the merchant in iron keep its a PVP covenant they also have special attacks like fire breath
the only problem with the game running at 60 fps is your weapons take more damage their durability is based on how many frames they're in contact with something

snippet.textDisplay:
You know you don't have to fight the Heide Knights right? They're non-agro enemies until you attack them. 

In vanilla they have a 100% drop rate for their weapons or armor pieces though, so you can get a decent sword early in Forest of the Fallen Giants given it already has a lightning attribute and pretty low stat requirements.

Overall I personally enjoy vanilla more, aside from the slightly better performance of SotFS. Still play my PS3 version quite frequently, up to NG+ 5 on my main character with a few other character builds in various NG cycles to play around with. I still think both versions are a far better experience than the first and third games though.

snippet.textDisplay:
The number of times you contradict yourself is funny. For example, you probably said the opposite of what you meant to when saying "this is a rare time where I think Sinner is better", when that's been the general thrust of the entire video. Or when you refer to footage you're not actually showing (talking about the enemies "here" when you're fighting the First Scholar). And your whole scoring system is subjective (which is correct, how could it be otherwise), so at the end when you say "these are just my biased versions 100%, nothing to do with the final score, nothing to do with the truth of what I believe is the best version", I have literally no idea what you're talking about, total word salad. You're constantly saying "objective" to just mean "reasonable" and "bias" to mean "unreasonable", when that's not what they mean at all.

You also say lots of minor things like "30 FPS sucks! *immediately say you get used to it and it's totally fine*" -- well, which is it? If it's fine, don't emphatically say it sucks. If it sucks, stick to your guns and don't say it's totally fine because you can get used to it. There are plenty of other instances. On top of that, you say "I don't remember, not sure" all the time, about half the distinctions you talk about. Really feel like there was no point in the video, as you have arbitrary opinions and not much info.

To be clear, it's perfectly fine to have an evolving opinion, or of course, different opinions on different parts of the game, or a very nuanced opinion that seems inconsistent, as long as you take time to justify it. And I'm not a fanboy who's overly sensitive, or anything like that. I'm genuinely writing this comment because I was enjoying the concept and the beginning, but there was such an accumulation of moments where I thought "wtf is this guy even trying to say", that I disliked the whole thing.

snippet.textDisplay:
One of the things I loved about Dark Souls 1 was just how powerful you could become very early on if you get the right equipment (spells, rings) and some lucky drops (black knight weapons). And even with that, there was still value in progression because you get better stuff and access to higher upgrades (via the embers) as you progressed

When DS2 came out, I was largely dissappointed in how difficult it was and how long it took to get the cool gear. Yeah you can get boss weapons early on, but for the most part they were balanced to be about as strong as their regular weapon counterparts so they werent as exciting to get

When Sinner came out, I was very happy with it because it actually made it a whole lot easier to get the cool, powerful gear. The strongest staff in the game, for example, is just past scorpioness najka, and a lot of cool armors were moved around to be reached early on if you bolt right to them. It also made some upgrade materials much easier to get. Its why I enjoyed all the persuers, they always drop twinkling titanite and I just generally enjoy fighting them because you can parry them

 I also felt that it made several areas less annoying in sinner over the original (though at the cost of some areas becoming much worse in sinner) and a lot of the enemy placement decisions were very fitting. Overall, I prefer Sinner over Vanilla

Imagine the approach to the Valiant Gargoyles in ER placed just two more enemies...two more Crucible Knights and poking one would immediately aggro the entire group. Would it matter that the absolute number of additional enemies would be low? No, because Crucible Knights are already plenty challenging when they're all by themselves. The problem with all the Alonne Knights in SotfS is that they're likewise aggro-chained so you always have the entire troupe on your toes if just one comes for you.

Yeah, sorry, complete disagree on your assessment of the Iron Keep here.

snippet.textDisplay:
First of all, thank you for this video! It is very well made, and was enjoyable to watch.

I didn't play Vanilla, so if someone wants to invalidate my point because of that, go ahead. However, judging solely by what I saw in this video, I think I wouldn't enjoy Vanilla as much as I enjoyed SotFS, and potentially why you enjoyed Sinner more.

To me personally, Dark Souls isn't about difficulty, death counts, ganks or anything like that. The most important part for me is experiences I get throughout my playthrough. Exploring a beautiful area, defeating a strong boss, finding a cool weapon and demolishing everyone with it, interacting with various NPCs -- all these things are major experiences that you will remember after finishing the game and maybe for much longer. However, minor experiences are as if not more important: they tie your playthrough together in a one complete journey and not just a collection of boss fights.

And I can't help but feel that SotFS excels at it much more than Vanilla does. You mention how you found cool that there are soldiers who attack trees of giants. I feel like if they were not there I would just think its a regular tree without anything interesting to it. However, because they are there, they make me wonder. Why are they attacking the tree? Is it special? Are they trying to cut it down? Did someone command them to do it? Because of all of that I make a memory about this suspicious tree and, consequently, create a connection with the game.

The dragon guardians in the Dragon Aerie create a sense of importance to the place. They help to provide the feeling that you are reaching a climax of your journey (or at least an important point of it). If the place were empty, I probably would just easily forget about it.

You mention the red dragon in the Heide's Tower of Flame as an extra unnecessary enemy. I, however, remember him as a memorable challenge to overcome: you have to either avoid or defeat all enemies prior to him, and then fight off with most likely your first dragon in the game. After that, the Old Dragonslayer bossfight itself feels like a reward (especially if you played DS1 before). Also, it kind of answers the question why Dragonrider doesn't ride a dragon -- the dragon just chills nearby.

Same goes for Heide Knights awakening after you defeat the Dragonrider, and many other different things -- they bring the world they inhabit to life. That is why I think I enjoyed DS2 as much as I did.

Again, I didn't play Vanilla myself, so I could just be completely wrong. Ultimately, I don't think the two versions are different enough for someone to argue that one is unarguably superior to the other. I would recommend SotFS to my friends simply because of better visuals.

snippet.textDisplay:
In my opinion people tend to hate scholar just because they can't handle the amount of enemies it introduces. 

Scholar haters will always talk about the Iron keep and about how many enemies it has. On the contrary I love a challenge, even if it is unfair (this is dark souls after all) and so I love the new enemies because they really force you to "git gud" if you want to finish the game.

Also in Shrine of Amana you just need a bow, end of story. It's good that a game forces you to adapt to different circumstances.

I love the extra Pursuer fights and new NPC invasions tbh. I also think vanilla in general feels really empty enemy-wise after getting used to SotFS. Overall the only change I don't like from Scholar to vanilla is the added dragon in Heide's. It doesn't feel like it belongs there and cheapens an already meh boss later on in Aldia's Keep. 

DS2 Scholar is my favorite Souls game. Was cool to see someone on here gassing it up for once. Thanks for the video.

snippet.textDisplay:
I actually prefer the Sinner's version of Shrine of Amana.

The second bonfire is the hardest one, and in Sinner's it's harder close to the bonfire, but it's easy once you reach the hut at the halfway point. In Vanilla the beginning of that part is easy, but after the hut you've got a lot more enemies and casters and you are more likely to lose minutes of progress.

In Sinner the last stretch is just way easier so it feels way less frustrating to me. If you die in the first part you only lose a tiny bit of progress.

snippet.textDisplay:
The water did affect the damage (it has a generous 5 minute duration), but your defense started too low.

The way elemental defenses work, each bonus gets better the more you stack bonuses, up to immunity at 900 defense. A sizable bonus is from INT and FTH so if those are your dump stats your elemental defenses are missing out on one of those stacking bonuses.

Fire is also the easiest defense to max out so the game compensates. Players who neglect their fire defense stats, armor, rings, etc all end up getting obliterated by pyromancers, desert sorceresses, fire hazards, and the smelter demon.

There's a reason why over 90% of players that played both versions prefer Scholar. Vanilla just lacks so many cool mechanics and quality of life improvements.

Scholar is the improved version with less ganks, less jank, more shortcuts, easier runbacks, more NPC summons, clearer path of progression, looks better, more stable 60 FPS, earlier access to the infusion coal and infinite Large Titanite Shards, earlier access to Shaded Woods, more quality of life features, more unique mechanics, more online activity, Dragon Shrine turned from one of the most annoying to one of the most beloved areas, spiders being afraid of the torch, you can hit the trees to distract the invisible enemies in the fog, etc

snippet.textDisplay:
While I don't agree with the vast majority of your assessments regarding Dark Souls 2 I really do appreciate the fact you made this video. I've recently completed SOTFS and I was curious to know the difference between that and the original. 

That being said, if you want to make a biased review or critique then do it. At the moment you are trying to do both and it isn't working. You can't use 'in my opinion' as much as you do in this video and claim to be unbiased at any point. You don't fall into the trap of telling people what is and isn't fun objectively but you do have a tendency to make objective statements backed up with subjective evidence. It's completely normal to do that, it's about being more careful with language than anything. This is why your response to asmongold was quite poor in terms of argumentation. 

Regardless, I do appreciate the alternate perspective your videos give me and I'm looking forward to more.

snippet.textDisplay:
Finally a comparison, I recently got vanilla on steam with DLCs really cheap price, I already had sinner on my ps4. I think dlcs did some changes on vanilla because the bonfire is in same place in Undead Cypt because Aldia appears. And soldiers rest have bonfire but different place. You should check steam version too. 

Okay, for my personel opinion, sinner is better. I love invaders, it makes game more challenging. I like Pursuer fights, I liked so many changes sinner did.

One big differrence I could say is, vanilla has more logical enemy placement but that doesn't make it more fun like crypt, so many enemy for Velstadt's road. What sinner made absolutely better is item placement. You got dull ember in Iron keep in vanilla, a really late area whether you choose Iron King first or later. It was in lost bastille, if you want infuse your weapon they gave you early opurtunity. 

For place to place comparison, 
Fotg-tie, that hollows attacking trees are nice addition but a little difficult for early area, vanilla handled better 
Heide's tower- I actually choose sinner. There is a new farming trick I found , it majes it better.
No man's wharf - sinner is better. Npc and shortway placement is better. Both version is annoying but sinner is better.
Lost Bastile- sinner is better by mile. That agressive mummys are horrible idea for Strait's cell. You can light the Lost Sinners room but you should know gargoyles place first. 
Huntsmen's Corps- sinner. It's nearly identical but addition of invaders make it better 
Harvest Valley-sinner. I think Vanilla's boss road has more gangs. Too many green stone hammer guys, I prefer desert sorcerers 😂.
Earthen peak- Vanilla. too much fast moving enemies in sinner. 
Iron Keep - wow all thw fuss is because of six more enemy, that's crazy. Sinner is better, thanks to invaders.
Shaded woods-sinner. Much better place in sinners version. You could fight Vengarl's body near the manscorpion Tark but you need branch.
Pharros door- tie. Much differrence, I always beat royal vanguard first and come this place later after I joined rat kings covenant. You never opened doors? There is Santiers Spear there, one of the best weapon. 
BCT-sinner. I don't know man, I liked sinner version more.
Gutter-vanilla. I think sinner has more enemy but I could be wrong.
Black Gulch- sinner. Again invaders.
Drangleic Castle- sinner by far, vanilla has much more gangs in this place, how people miss it.
Shrine of Amana- vanilla, less annoying, less enemies.
Undead Cypt - sinner. Big improvement over vanilla.
Aldia's Keep-sinner. The dragon skelaton drops Aldia's key in sinner version. It opens one room and there are good items. I 
think in vanilla otems are in different place.
Dragon Aerie-tie, mostly similar, I don't like that dragon trick in vanilla either but I think it has less gang.
 Dragon Shirine- sinner by far. 
Memories- tie, I belive second giant memory has two giant more but I could be wrong about.

snippet.textDisplay:
i have a question for the community, why an area that is harder is objectively a bad thing? "because is just annoying" no, because u have to learn how to play the game, am i so much wrong? why i like all the "worst" places in this game? maybe cuz i play it since day 1 vanilla preorder edition? probably, even if so, im good at this game cuz i learned from it.
speaking for a first experience shrine of amana was hell in vanilla before the patch, but still the satisfaction of beating that area was so good - like VirJohnity said, "ganks r not a problem i have a Greatsword" the fast attack 1hand is god tier for crowd control, and is not only for this weapon - even if so, the problem with ganks often comes from our positioning, positioning is key. just git gud guys!

snippet.textDisplay:
I understand ur point on ganks. The thing that is annoying to me and many others is not that we can't deal with it but that it is annoying and cheap. It feels like the game wants to proof so badly that it is "hard" that it throughs everything at u at once hoping u die. Normallly in every other soulsgame enemies are introduced to u one at a time and when they come together most of the time u need a strategy to take them out easier while DS II just swarms u so u heard the enemies in a tight space and chop them down. 
Obviously none of that applies to every situation just trying to give an overview here.
The main point being imo that if u get swarmed in DS1 or 3 its ur mistake for pulling to much while in DS2 its the norm way more often.
